factoid: Prince Andrew continually hurt Princess Mary's feelings and tormented her.
It cost Princess Mary no effort to forgive Prince Andrew.
Princess Mary's father loved her in spite of everything.
The complex laws of man are centered for Princess Mary in the law of love and self-sacrifice.
The law of love and self-sacrifice is taught by Him who lovingly suffered for mankind and is God.
Princess Mary endured and loved.
Prince Andrew came to Bald Hills during the winter.
Prince Andrew was gay, gentle, and more affectionate than Princess Mary had known him for a long time.
Princess Mary felt something had happened to Prince Andrew, but Prince Andrew said nothing to her about his love.
Before leaving, Prince Andrew had a long talk with his father about something.
Prince Andrew and his father were dissatisfied with one another before his departure.
Princess Mary wrote to Julie Karágina in Petersburg.
Julie Karágina was mourning her brother who was killed in Turkey.
Sorrow is our common lot.
The narrator explains the loss as a special providence of God who loves Julie and wishes to try her and her mother.
Religion can save us from despair.
Religion alone can explain why kind and noble beings are called away to God while cruel, useless, harmful persons are left living.
The narrator's first death seen was that of his dear sister-in-law.
The death of the narrator's dear sister-in-law left an impression on him.
The narrator asks why angel Lise, who never wronged anyone and had no unkind thoughts, had to die.
Five years after Lise's death, the narrator sees clearly why she died and that her death was an expression of the infinite goodness of the Creator.
The infinite goodness of the Creator manifests through His infinite love for His creatures.
The narrator thinks Lise was too angelically innocent to have the strength to perform all a mother's duties.
As a young wife Lise was irreproachable; perhaps she could not have been so as a mother.
Lise left the narrator and particularly Prince Andrew with the purest regrets and memories.
Lise's early and terrible death had the most beneficent influence on the narrator and his brother despite all grief.
The narrator writes to convince Julie of the Gospel truth that not a single hair of our heads will fall without God's will.
God's will is governed only by infinite love for us, and whatever befalls us is for our good.
